bookmarks.note: Yet. But, if the indexes are market weighted, as long as you have humans running them, there is always the chance that they will attempt to increase their profits at the expense of others
But if they use the same underlying index then it would run a foul of IRS regulations? Would it be considered a wash sale in that case?
I don‚Äôt get it. Why is that a problem? Why not trade in and out of ETFs? Taxes? Wash sales? Commissions and loads and fees and bid-ask spreads?

In kind redemptions at ETFs are basically a tax cheat that regular index funds and mutual funds cannot take advantage of. When you redeem, instead of selling the shares and having you pay taxes on the ETFs cost basis, which may be two dollars for a specific stock, instead, they give you the shares themselves, and let you sell them, so you end up paying taxes at a cost basis of whatever the price of that stock was when you bought the ETF (for example, you might have that same Company stock at a cost basis of $25). At the same time, the ETF doesn't have to pay taxes on that two dollar share, because the share that they now hold has a cost basis of $25. So that $23 capital gain just proof disappears into thin air, and no one has to ever pay taxes on it. Did I get that right?
Emil no longer recommends buying the S&P 500. He actually prefers the CRSP inflation index or the Russell 3000
Here‚Äôs him telling me what to buy
Is it 5%? If inflation rises by 5%, wouldn‚Äôt you need a nominal return of $105%*105%=110.25%$ to net a real return of 5%, rather than 110.00%?

Yes, but how much did it make its owners by allowing them to sell other things throughout that time? You walk into someone's home who says that he owns a da Vinci, and he can mark up everything else that he owns.
For Mom: how to save

So as I understand it, if I create a negative Beta portfolio and the market increases and my portfolio decreases, but it decreases less than would be protected by the $beta*market$, I am said to have produced alpha? Or is this true, but does alpha only matter in the case where your performance is at least as good as that of the market itself
Why to consider a variable annuity: if you've maxed out on all the other tax-deferred savings alternatives.
This is exactly what Toly's ping-pong strategy was based on. He would just basically be a wall, and wait until the other person made a mistake. I guess it was based on sound economic theory.

That's absolutely insane. 95% of all stock market returns went on 90 days out of 7500 Study

So it's the same thing that mom and I realized. You can find something that is profitable, but it won't make money unless you have no transactions cost. So you have to trade the stock itself, and you have to be happy with the returns you get.

What I'm getting from this is that it's likely that Simons‚Äô mystical 66% CAGR medallion fund is also likely a scam, where they front run their public funds‚Äô purchases and front run their sales. But, then again, they do hire leading physicists and mathematicians with PhDs in the hard sciences. So maybe it *is* an exception

I should run this test myself. Use the strategy of comparing buy at 5% from low and sell at 5% from high, or 7%, or whatever. Run a Python simulation that takes all the prices over the past N days. 3 parameters: N days, percent_off_low to buy at, percent_off_high to sell at. Download the data, and then run the test. Do the same thing with 15 minute data during various periods of time. Backtest throughout history, backtest using specific time periods (e.g. ZIRP era, QT eras, QE eras, infinite since stock IPO, etc.)
So this is basically advocating for following trends
This is exactly what this book is about. And what I need to know when I try to trade based purely on technicals. Random walk. You have to have fundamentals. You can use technicals to make more money.
